English: Postmaster Belsky!
You again...
Will you finally tell me why are my letters not going through?
Comrade Ablomov, you have been nagging me for days now. Don't you have other things to do?
I'm not leaving until you tell me.
I'll repeat what I already told you - our supply routes are long and there have been delays.
Comrade Belsky, just yesterday I saw a number of new ships in the port unloading cargo.
Weapons and medecine are of higher priority and they get through the delays quicker...
Bullshit! I could have believed you few weeks back, but I know that's not the case!
Everything was smooth while we were fighting on Kolguyev! Ever since our victory and reconquest of Everon, I have not received a single reply and I doubt my letters are going through either.
Should I ask around and find out how many other soldeirs have the same issue even if they themselves do not realize it?
This is unbecoming of you. I should report you to your commanding officer!
Do that, I don't care. The more people we involve, the better. Everyone should be concerned there is no communication between us and the mainland!
Alright, not so loud! You don't know what you're getting yourself into!
So, you admit there is something going on. Talk.
It is dangerous, comrade Ablomov, you have no idea. It is far greater than you or me. You should drop it and walk away.
I already said I'm not going anywhere. Tell me.
Nobody outside my group should know. You must keep it to yourself, no questions!
Alright, alright, just tell me already!
There has been an order - from very high up - to cut off all communication to and from the archipelago. Letters, packages, telegrams, fax messages - nothing gets through.
There is a big warehouse on Kolguyev where all items are stored. They are not forwarded to their recipients.
Why would someone do that?
Why, comrade Ablomov, think! Who would have the necessary authority? Who would have a reason? Who would benefit from it?
Comrade Lemontov, welcome. Now, we're only awaiting the arrival of comrade Volkov. You haven't met with comrade Kukushkin, have you? Our new tank corps commander.
It is an honour and a pleasure, comrade Lemontov.
I heard comrade Frolov died. How did it happen?
It was a bloody battle in the hills of Kolguyev. We were outnumbered, but he fought like a lion. We won, but comrade Frolov died later in the hospital.
Did he have his sunglasses on him?
I'm not sure, we never found them.
Comrade Army general, colonel Vladimir Volkov!
At ease, comrades.

Comrade Kukushkin, I am glad you decided to join us. Together we shall build a better future for our descendants. Most people are too afraid and lack the will to do what is necessary. You are not among them.
I'm at your command, comrade Volkov!
Comrade Lemontov, I've been given reports of your activies on Everon. You have done well and proved that you are still the same comrade who was taken from us seven years ago.
Forgive me for not trusting you sooner, I had to be careful. We weren't quite sure whether you returned a completely different man or perhaps even a spy.
It's alright, comrade Volkov. I would not have trusted myself either.
Now that we can be open with each other, it is time to finish what you started so long ago. And there is only one place where that can be done.
Malden.
It is obvious, but yes, Malden. The impenetrable fortress of the enemy is well within our grasp. It is there the age old conflict between west and east shall be decided.
What you began seven years ago with comrade Livanokh, we shall finish today.
But we failed. What makes you think you will succeed?
You bit off more than you could chew. Taking over the whole island is indeed a remarkable feat.
But that is not our goal. I recognize the mistakes of the past and I am not about to repeat them.
What is our strategy then?
Step by step, we got where we are today. Luring the Americans to overstep and interfere on Everon. Defending Kolguyev and getting stronger with each coming ship and plane.
Backing of Kremlin is one thing, but comrade Livanokh never received substantial support he required and when the tide turned, he was betrayed. We made sure that can not happen.
We swept through Everon and destroyed all local resistance. The only thing that stands between us and victory is Malden.
Step by step, we shall remove that last obstacle out of the way and finally achieve comrade Livanokh's dream - destroying the western vermin once and for all.
I ask again, what is our strategy?
There is a facility on the island built after the last war. Shrouded in secrecy and mystery as well as heavily guarded. A top secret.
We managed to get a glimpse of what's inside. The Americans are developing a new type of weapon, deadly weapon. It looks to be of nuclear origin and is strong enough to wipe out entire cities.
On Malden? Are you absolutely sure?
Positive. I couldn't believe it myself the first time I heard it, but it's true. We obtained irrefutable evidence.
They might have chosen this area to be able to test it on us on Kolguyev, the bastards.
How is that possible? It's too far fetched to be true, surely? I would have known, I would have realized...
But it does makes sense. Is this what George meant? They cannot get hold of that weapon!
We shall take control of it and use it against them. Reduce their cities on the western coast to dust.
That should send a clear message to our enemies as well as friends. Taking control of the Soviet Union after that will be child's play.

What about Kremlin? They can't seriously support this?
STRM_x04v60,Their opinion is of no matter to us. We have everything we require and their blessing is no longer necessary."
Let me show you, comrade Lemontov.
Soldiers of the Red Army!
Everon has been finally reclaimed! Its people are now safe under our protection and it is only thanks to you and your courage! I salute you, comrades!
We have achieved a great victory today and a moment like this calls for a celebration! Each and every will receive a bottle of vodka to properly toast to your success!
The enemy has been vanquished and retreated to his home island of Malden! The Red Army stands victorious!
Alas, our work is not yet done.
I have received a telegram from the General Secretary himself. The Kremlin has more orders for us!
Our victory pleases them and they want us to continue - to finish the work we started by taking over Malden and kicking the enemy out of the area once and for all!
It is the only way to peace! A total victory, comrades, is within our grasp!
Controlling the narrative. I doubt Kremlin is aware of any of this, perhaps even the reconquest of Everon.
He can't get away with it!
What would you be able to do about it? Just lower your head and follow orders, this is above you and me.
Will you follow me to the island of Malden and claim it for Mother Russia? Will you be part of the greatest victory over the west in our lifetime?!
Will you bring fame and glory to our nation one last time?! To victory, I say, to Malden!
Malden! Malden! Malden!
Look at Lemontov, standing with the others like he's part of them now. It makes me sick.
This was his plan all along, it seems it worked out.
His plan involved butchering the last remnants of free people of Everon?
Of course not, but Grigory is willing to go far to reach his goal.
Too far if you ask me. What exactly has he achieved?
He's in their group. A very dangerous position, but he should have now access to their information and plans and can act accordingly to stop them.
I hope it was worth for him. I would not be able to sleep with his conscience.
He's done a lot of questinable things in his life. Some very dark and tragic. Maybe this is his way of atoning for his sins.
Atoning for old sins while commiting new ones.
He very much believes the end justifies the means. Volkov needs to be stopped, Sergey, the incredible danger he poses is very much worth the lives of few rebels.
So you are on his side, great. I still don't understand why he couldn't simply ask Volkov or Zubarev about his plans. Why all the secrecy?
He's done something that they would not approve of - they would kill him. If he didn't tell you, I am not going to. But you should ask him, it concerns you as well.
It does not.
It concerns your father.
I asked him twice about my father's death and he evaded the question both times. He doesn't trust me, even after what we've been through.

He was never honest with me. He knows how my father died and refuses to tell me the truth. He does what most benefits him and his grandiose goal of saving the world from whatever Volkov is supposedly after.
He is a dangerous...
I could not care less anymore. If you don't trust me, I don't have a reason to trust you. I'll never forgive him for what he's done, no matter how noble reasoning he had.
I believe he could have acted differently, there is always a choice. He chose his way and I am choosing mine.
Do whatever you wish about Volkov and Zubarev, this does not concern me anymore. I am done.
Chapter IV\n\nH O M E C O M I N G
